docs.snippet: Mikhail S. Gorbachev assailed a decision by a Russian court to ban him from traveling abroad today, calling it a violation of human rights.    "The first Soviet President has been turned into the first political 'refusenik' of Russia," said a stat...
docs.lead_paragraph: Mikhail S. Gorbachev assailed a decision by a Russian court to ban him from traveling abroad today, calling it a violation of human rights. "The first Soviet President has been turned into the first political 'refusenik' of Russia," said a statement issued by Mr. Gorbachev's press office, using a term once given to dissidents who were denied exit visas by the authorities in the former Soviet Union.

headline.main: Gorbachev Calls Travel Curb a Violation of Human Rights

docs.snippet: The Justice Department announced today that it would not file criminal charges against Ramsey Clark, the former Attorney General, who defied President Carter's ban on travel to Iran by attending a conference in Teheran last June.   Mr. Carter said...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Justice Department announced today that it would not file criminal charges against Ramsey Clark, the former Attorney General, who defied President Carter's ban on travel to Iran by attending a conference in Teheran last June. Mr. Carter said in June that it was his ''inclination'' to prosecute Mr. Clark because his trip could have endangered the safety of the American hostages in Iran. But today Attorney General Benjamin R. Civiletti said that ''no indictments will be sought'' against Mr. Clark or the nine Americans who went with him to the conference on United States ''intervention'' in Iran.

headline.main: CLARK IS NOT FACING U.S. CRIMINAL ACTION

byline.original: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to the New York Times
